The front wheels of a car are at a constant angle relative to how you steer. If you begin turning while going backwards, the front wheels will not continue straight relative to the ground, but will remain at the same angle, maintaining a constant turn. What makes driving backwards difficult is having to turn around to see where you're going. The same is true for forklifts, which become harder to drive backwards than they are forwards.

Forklifts have steering in the back for two reasons I can think of. It allows for the load to be most stable when turning and it allows for the joints to angle a lot sharper, allowing for a 0 radius turn, making them super maneuverable.

For cars, because of their potential for high velocity, turning with the front wheels is just more stable.

Lol at the balancing-an-axe part :-) I always find it an interesting puzzle to reverse with a trailer. I worked a few months at an airport, doing the luggage, enough opportunities to reverse with 4 trailers :D Also interesting if the trailer has a towbar with a turning point at the center between the front wheels.

Also a big factor is the caster of the steering wheels (front wheels) nearly all cars have a positive caster which provides the front wheels with great stability and self centering while going forward, but becomes unstable and wants to go off center when going in reverse. This becomes more noticeable at higher speeds.

The difficulty with driving backwards isn't which set of wheels are turning. The main issue is that you are looking over your shoulder and across the length of the car when driving in reverse. In other words, the driver has difficulty seeing where the car is going. If the stearing wheel were in a reverse facing back seat, driving forward would be difficult.

Ugh, I hate miseducation, especially if the people doing it pretend to be all 'scientific' about it.

1. It is not harder to drive backwards. I 'drive backwards' for my work. It makes very little difference.
2. When driving backwards, your direction isn't determined by the rear wheels: if this were true, you'd not be able to steer at all since the rear wheels are always pointing in the exact same direction. The direction you're going in is determined by where your front wheels are not pointing.

Please MinutePhysics, get your facts straight and your shit together. This way you're doing the opposite of making people smarter.

The video is COMPLETELY WRONG until it gets to the part about trailers - then it's right. At low speed, if you're traveling forward, if you want to go to the place that's on the right, you turn the steering wheel to the right. If you're traveling backward, Looking In The Mirror, if you want to go to the place that's on the right, you turn the wheel to the right. Exactly the same! When you understand that, and practice it, it's no big deal. In both cases, you're turning the steering wheel toward the side of the car that you want the car to go to. Instability is not an issue. (At low speed. At higher speed, you get "oversteer", just like pushing a shopping cart backwards, but that's a separate issue.)Suppose you're not looking in a mirror, but turning your head around. But then you're confused by your head and your body having different opinions of where "right" is. So turn your whole body around, sit on the dashboard facing backward. (Have a good friend work the pedals.) It's exactly the same as if you were driving forward (except for the "oversteer" business if you're not going slow).
On the other hand, if you're trying to back up a trailer, it helps if your wheelbase is short, and the trailer's is long. Semi-drivers do that all the time. But if the trailer's wheelbase is short, it's very challenging, as it was when I was driving a tractor on a farm.

Hi, as an ex-driving instructor and scientist I need to explain that it is in fact not hard to steer backwards. I have given demonstrations of driving down country roads at 80 km/h in reverse. The instability you talk about is because of the "tow in" set on the front wheels. That is the left wheel is set to turn slightly to the right and the right wheel slightly to the left. The result of this is the car has a tendency to naturally steer straight if you let go of the steering wheel. However "tow in" going forward is "tow out" going backwards. So a car configured to be stable going forwards is hence configured to be unstable going the other way. Any car could be configured by a mechanic to be stable going backwards and not stable driving forwards.
Not really that hard to drive in reverse if you drive a fork lift all the time
Four wheel steering.
You should do a skit on way you need bigger and more powerful brakes on the front wheels of cars and smaller brakes on the back.

Note: This also effects bikes, and planes, although planes slightly differently. A plane with canards at the front doesn't need to wait to be rotated, and the force from pulling the canards in a direction is exactly how you'd expect, in that direction.

On the other hand, a conventional aircraft, with elevators in the back, will sink somewhat from using them until the wings turn up sufficiently to generate more lift. In other words, the elevators compete with the wings, instead of adding to them.

On the other hand, canards (and bike and car front wheels) at a high angle of attack will normally stall before the wing (or the back tire). In a neutrally stable vehicle without a lot of angular inertia relative to the rotational drag, this is probably beneficial, but in other vehicles, it will limit angle of attack.

As a forklift driver, I must take exception to the claim that driving with rear wheel control is harder than front wheel.  The difference is merely a matter of experience.   We all learn on front wheel control vehicles (typically automobiles, but also trucks, motorcycles and bicycles).  So we think of them as "natural."  If we learned first on rear wheel controlled vehicles, we would think of them as natural and find front wheel controls challenging.

I find the physics discussion about the difference between front and rear control interesting and I don't dispute that.  I dispute only the subjective "humans find this or that easier."

I think the instability thing isn't true with cars (it is true with trailers). It is based on the assumption, that the front wheels go in the same direction (relative to the ground) regardless of what the rest of the car is doing. This is of course not true, because the front wheels are fixed to the car, and their angle relative to the car stays the same. So it will go in a circle (as mentioned at the beginning), regardless of which way the car is going.

You don't point your front wheels where you want to go in a normal car, you can't even see the things. You turn your steering wheel in the direction you want to go, and that doesn't change when you go backward. The real reason it's harder to drive backward is because you're in an unaccustomed, uncomfortable position, which is distracting, and if you're turning your upper body along with your neck, it means you have to move your arms at an unaccustomed angle to reach the wheel.

There's something you missed that has a very important effect on driving backwards: when car is traveling in a straight line, in order to increase stability the wheels are not all parallel to the direction, the front ones diverge in front of the car while the back ones converge in front of the car. If you drive the car backwards this combination is reversed making the car very unstable.

Um, what? If I hold the wheel steady and reverse, I make a nice, controlled arc, equally as controlled as driving forwards. The picture you have with the front wheel staying in a fixed position w.r.t. to road (leading to the car "falling over like an inverted pendulum") is completely divorced from reality. Once you add trailers on the back, sure, it becomes unstable, but ONLY then.

The difference is only that the simplistic strategy of pointing the steering wheels towards the destination (where the driver is actually providing the positive feedback leading to instability) doesn't work with reversing, whereas it does work going forwards.

How was this analyzed? 

I have heard vehicle dynamics experts explain it is still a "stable" dynamic system, i.e. rear wheel steer.  It just seems unstable because the car yaws in a direction contrary to what the driver expects.  If a slip angle is induced in the rear, (rear wheel steer) the front would react Fy due to the slip angle (using SAE coordinates).  The moments still balance.  Look up Milliken Moment Method, refer to Gillespie's Fundamentals of Vehicle Dynamics, and Milliken&Kasprzak's Race Car Vehicle Dynamics.

You analysis at 1:03 assumes the steering isn't at a fixed slip angle.  This same problem would happen if the car is moving forward or backward with front wheel steering, depending on what the caster is.

Vehicle dynamics is a complicated subject, and this video does not in my opinion do justice in providing the viewer accurate information.

This video might not be true.

I've always found that driving backwards is pretty simple when you understand that the direction you turn the wheel is the direction the car will move, regardless of whether you're driving forwards or backwards.

1.  Position your vehicle in the diagonally adjacent in front of your desired parking spot.

Very similar to the difference in learning to fly in an old Cessna 140 taildragger vs a newer Cessna 150 with a nose wheel.  On the taildragger once the CG get swung over to one side it wants to do a ground loop.  On the nosewheel plane, it wants to center itself. I think you guys are just shitty drivers...... No problems driving backwards here....

Steering stability in vehicles is drastically effected by caster angle, especially at higher speeds. The caster angle in passenger cars is designed so that, when travelling forward, it forces the wheels used for steering to center themselves when no steering input is supplied by the operator.  As in the trailer example, this adds an extra layer of instability when traveling in reverse. Vehicles with rear steering designs have a different caster angle to take this into account.

This is a nice video that I'm going to share with my coworkers and boss.  I regularly drive a forklift AND back trailers.  I've gotten rather good at it, because I've taken the time to focus on my vehicle's size, wheel-base, steering angles, pivot points, and directional vectors.  I can do it by "feel" on most vehicles now, but see others struggle.  I always think "You are struggling because you think you are doing one thing, but really, many things are happening at once, and you need to understand how they connect."

This video illuminates all of that nicely!  Thanks.

When you steer the front wheels, you're judging the direction that the front wheels are pointed based on where they go as you move. When you reverse, the rear wheels go straight backwards, so if you just observe the position of the rear wheels like you normally would the front, you're getting none of the usual feedback for how to steer things. This loss of feedback is what makes things hard.

If you imagine your car is twice as long as it actually is, extending past the back wheels by another car length, then the steering wheel directly controls the imaginary far end of the extended car. You can see this by just drawing the mirror image of your car (reflected across the rear axle); the three pairs of wheels (front, back, reflected front) are symmetric, so there really is no difference between forwards and backwards.

This mirroring is easier to see with the forklift. The forks act as your imaginary extension, so you just steer the tips of the forks as you would steer the front of a car. The important thing here is the 'back' wheels aren't actually at the back; they're roughly midway between the steering wheels and the fork tips.

For a car, just steer the car based on looking beyond the back end of the car. As long as your attention is far enough away, it's no different than going forwards.

OK, one thing. There is an adjustment on your vehicle's wheels called caster.  Which is why your wheels automatically want to go strait when you drive forward.  Just like the wheels on a shopping cart, except on a vehicle the wheels can't turn all the way around.  So,  due to this caster adjustment, when driving in reverse your vehicle will naturally want to go anywhere but strait. Forklifts have little to no caster adjustment on their turning wheels allowing for easier forward and backward driving.
